fields.recommendation: Identify what policies, procedures, and initiatives the Company has implemented to identify and mitigate the risks of bribery and related corruption? What training does it provide staff, does it employ third party services such as for whistleblowing and how does it manage its supply chain? The use of third-party sales agents required particular attention.
Disclose issues concerning customer privacy, and incidents of losses of customer data and breaches of customer privacy. This can also include data on complaints from regulatory bodies.

Publication of total annual energy consumed (gigajoules) and percentage renewable (e.g., wind, biomass, solar).
Disclose the organisation's energy consumption data by source along with any policies, plans and initiatives to increase energy efficiency, and develop and disclose a low-carbon energy transition strategy including targets and KPIs.

Diversity at all levels of the business; disclosure of percentage of employees by gender in the board, senior management positions and all other employee positions.
Equality in remuneration, considering ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men by employee category and significant locations of operation. If there is a significant difference, explain why there is a difference. 
Whether the company systems have policies/programmes promoting equal opportunities (regardless of gender and other diversities) that explicitly extends to the entire value chain.
Whether there is increased access to information and technology for women (women's participation in programs enhancing the use of enabling technologies).

Training provided to employees, with disclosure on average hours of training per year, employee gender and employee category.
Type and scope of programs implemented and assistance provided to upgrade employee skills, and whether there are transition assistance programs provided to facilitate continued employability and management of career endings resulting from retirement or termination of employment.
Employee hires, with disclosure on total number and rate by age group, gender and region. 
Employee turnover, with disclosure on total number and rate by age group, gender and region.

Carbon management and disclosure of year-on-year trends data for scope, 1, 2 and 3 emissions. If you are unable to account for scope 3 emission, the company should be able to disclose and explain any exclusions.
The extent of emissions of ozone-depleting substances (ODS).
NOX, SOX, and other significant air emissions.
The company should seek sector specific guidance on substances which lowers air quality, if material to the business. (For example, for the oil and gas sector, disclose the level of benzene, lead and Sulphur content in fuels).

Public statement on if and where the company will work against corruption in all its forms, including bribery and extortion.
The organization states publicly if and where it will work against corruption in all its forms, including bribery and extortion.
Issues related to corruption around company operations, confirmed incidents of corruption, how they have been assessed and actions taken. 
Communication and training on anti-corruption policies and procedures, to include data relating to number, type, location of employee who have been communicated to and received training.

Publication of total annual energy consumed (gigajoules) and percentage renewable (e.g., wind, biomass, solar).
Disclose the organisation's energy consumption data by source along with any policies, plans and initiatives to increase energy efficiency, and develop and disclose a low-carbon energy transition strategy including targets and KPIs.

Identify and disclose aspects of the company's operations and supply chain that involve the procurement, use, and storage of hazardous materials, and ensure compliance with relevant national and international regulatory standards (e.g. REACH, GHS, CLP). 
Develop and disclose a sustainable chemicals management strategy, including a proactive substitution strategy with respect to the REACH Candidate List.

Evidence of diversification, technological upgrading and innovation in the business to meet environmental and social demands. This can include issues like resource efficiency, reuse-and recycle as well as responsibility in product design.
Actions which have been undertaken to reduce energy requirements for products and services, with data on reduction in energy requirements of sold products/service, and method of calculation. 
Percentage of products sold that are collected, reused or recycled.
Percentage of recycled input materials used to manufacture the organization’s primary products and services.

Adherence to relevant water standards, and percent of facilities which do this.
Water discharge and quality, with disclosure by destination in megalitres per year for all facilities.
Hazardous and non-hazardous waste by type (e.g. reuse, landfill, incineration, etc.) and disposal method by weight.
If material to the sector, discuss significant spills, to include location, value and material of spill.
Monetary value of significant fines and total number of non-monetary sanctions for non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations.

Infringement on human rights of local communities (e.g. rights of indigenous people), and disclosure of total incidents.
Report the internal and external mechanisms for seeking advice on ethical and lawful behaviour, and matters related to organizational integrity, such as helplines or advice lines.
Disclose details of grievances about human rights impacts filed, addressed, and resolved through formal grievance mechanisms.

Energy consumption from both outside and within the organization, providing information (e.g. fuel types) on both renewable and non-renewable sources in MWh.
Energy intensity ratio, specific metric used to calculate the ratio and types of energy which have been included in the intensity ratio.  
Reduction of overall energy consumption, giving information on types of energy included in the reduction, and calculation method. 
How much fuel, electricity, heat, steam, and cooling in MWh has your organisation purchased and consumed during the reporting year?
How the company is monitoring and managing it's greenhouse gas emissions. Has there been disclosure of year-on-year trends for scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions?

Disclosure of incidents by type and rates of injury,  lost days, absenteeism, and total number of work-related fatalities, along with occupational diseases, by region and gender.
Proportion of workers who experience high incidence or high risk of diseases and health hazard related to their occupation. 
For companies with supply chains in countries that experience high levels of HIV, to disclose the proportion of both male and female workers along the value chain that have access to free and voluntary HIV testing (either through their employer or public/community health systems).

Help strengthen the capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking, insurance and financial services for all.
Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

Describe the organization's values, principles, standards and norms of behaviour such as codes of conduct and codes of ethics.
Report the internal and external mechanisms for reporting concerns about unethical or unlawful behaviour, and matters related to organizational integrity, such as escalation through line management, whistleblowing mechanisms or hotlines.
Report the internal and external mechanisms for seeking advice on ethical and lawful behaviour, and matters related to organizational integrity, such as helplines or advice lines.
Identify and disclose the total number of legal actions for anti-competitive behaviour, anti-trust, and monopoly practices and their outcomes.

Evidence of systems in place to identify significant risk in operations and suppliers for incidents of forced or compulsory labour, and measures to contribute to the elimination of all forms of forced or compulsory labour.
Evidence that the company and its suppliers have consistent practices for informing and/or training workers on their rights under national labour and employment law.
Disclosure on percentage of total and new suppliers that have been screened using labour practices criteria. 
Incidents where significant actual and potential negative impacts for labour practices in the supply chain and actions taken.
Water withdrawal by source (e.g. surface water - wetlands, rivers and lakes), location, and give information on calculation method.

Issues related to corruption around company operations, confirmed incidents of corruption, how they have been assessed and actions taken. 
Communication and training on anti-corruption policies and procedures, to include data relating to number, type, location of employee who have been communicated to and received training.

Express commitment to empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
Disclose composition of governance bodies and breakdown of employees per employee category according to gender, age group, minority group membership, and other indicators of diversity.
Develop, implement and disclose policies/programmes promoting equal opportunities (regardless of gender and other diversities) both within the company and extending to the entire value chain.
Describe policies and practices used to promote economic inclusion when selecting suppliers. Forms of economic inclusion may include: suppliers owned by women; suppliers owned or staffed by members of vulnerable, marginalized or underrepresented social groups; and small and medium sized suppliers.

Publication of total annual energy consumed (gigajoules) and percentage renewable (e.g., wind, biomass, solar).
Disclose the organisation's energy consumption data by source along with any policies, plans and initiatives to increase energy efficiency, and develop and disclose a low-carbon energy transition strategy including targets and KPIs.

Percentage of products sold and their packaging materials that are collected, reused or recycled.
Total weight or volume of materials that are used to package the organization’s primary products and services, by non-renewable materials used and renewable materials used.

Systems which the company is dependent on to operate (e.g. financial, technology) and related risks to business continuity. Additionally, identify the highest level of governance (i.e. board accountability) in managing related risks.
Companies in the financial sector to report on results of stress tests under adverse economic scenarios, to include measures such as actual and projection loan losses, revenue, net income before taxes, Tier 1 common capital ratio, Tier 1 capital ratio. Companies to also report on liquidity and registered and unregistered assets under management.
Companies in the telecommunications sectors to report on number of performance issues and service disruptions and total customer downtime. Disclosure shall include a description of each significant performance issue or service disruption and any corrective actions taken to prevent future disruptions.

Identify what steps the Company has taken to prevent ant-competitive behaviour anti-trust, and monopoly practices and their outcomes. Does it have and communicate codes of conduct and codes of ethics to all staff? Does it have internal and external mechanisms for seeking advice and reporting concerns such as whistleblowing mechanisms or hotlines?

Identify the Company's procurement, use, and storage of hazardous materials. Is it compliant with relevant national and international regulations on overall use (e.g. REACH in the EU), storage and handling, and disposal? Has it developed and disclose a sustainable chemicals management strategy, including a proactive substitution strategy for Substances of Very High Concern (SVHC).

Identify the policies and systems the Company has implemented to ensure business continuity. Has this been undertaken as a voluntary initiative or a regulatory requirement? Has it identified the systems it is dependent on to operate (e.g. financial, technology)? Does it currently monitor and report on performance or service disruption issues and any corrective actions taken?

Identify the Company's hazardous and non-hazardous waste by type and disposal method (e.g. reuse, recycling, incineration, or landfill). Does it operate in compliance with regulatory requirements? Do these include paying a tax, for instance on packaging waste? Has it put in place measures to minimise the volumes generated, and that going to incineration or landfill?

Identify where the Company sources its water from and whether it has assessed current or future scarcity issues. Determine whether its supply is regulated and whether its uses are in competition with other users (particularly in the local community) and/or to be impacting local ecosystems. Assess whether the Company has put in place measures to minimise its water use.
